labels.analysis: The MCP Server, "Databutton," appears to be focused on application development, particularly in building and deploying business applications. The description mentions generating initial app plans and creating foundations using React and Python APIs, suggesting a toolkit for developers. The sole available tool, "submit_app_requirements," indicates that the server helps users define and manage application requirements, likely contributing to faster and more streamlined development processes.
labels.reasoning: The primary label "Development Tools" was chosen because the server's core functionality revolves around assisting in application development, particularly with front-end (React) and back-end (Python APIs) technologies. The secondary label "AI/ML Tools" was considered due to the mention of "AI agent" in the description, which might imply automated or intelligent components in the app-building process. However, since it's not specified, this might not be accurate. No custom label is needed as the server's functionality aligns well with pre-existing categories.

server_info_crawled.name: Databutton
server_info_crawled.author: @databutton/databutton-mcp
server_info_crawled.overview: Build and deploy beautiful business apps effortlessly with our AI agent. Generate initial app plans and create a solid foundation for your projects using React and Python APIs. Streamline your development process and unleash unbounded complexity with ease.

description.description: The app's specifications given in no more than 4-5 paragraphs

server_info_crawled.python_sdk:
import mcp
from mcp.client.streamable_http import streamablehttp_client
import json
import base64

smithery_api_key = ""
url = f"https://server.smithery.ai/@databutton/databutton-mcp/mcp?api_key={smithery_api_key}"

async def main():
    # Connect to the server using HTTP client
    async with streamablehttp_client(url) as (read_stream, write_stream, _):
        async with mcp.ClientSession(read_stream, write_stream) as session:
            # Initialize the connection
            await session.initialize()
            # List available tools
            tools_result = await session.list_tools()
            print(f"Available tools: {', '.join([t.name for t in tools_result.tools])}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    import asyncio
    asyncio.run(main())
